org.jnetpcap.protocol.sigtran

�� Sctp

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jnetpcap.nio.JMemory

  • ������ʵ�ֵĽӿ�:
    JHeaderChecksum, JPayloadAccessor

    @Header(length=12,
        suite=SIGTRAN,
        description="Stream Control Transmission Protocol")
public class Sctp
extends JHeader
implements JHeaderChecksum
    In computer networking, the Stream Control Transmission Protocol (SCTP) is a transport layer protocol, serving in a similar role to the popular protocols Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) and User Datagram Protocol (UDP). It provides some of the same service features of both: it is message-oriented like UDP and ensures reliable, in-sequence transport of messages with congestion control like TCP.

    The protocol was defined by the IETF Signaling Transport (SIGTRAN) working group in 2000,[1] and is maintained by the IETF Transport Area (TSVWG) working group. RFC 4960 defines the protocol. RFC 3286 provides an introduction.

    In the absence of native SCTP support in operating systems it is possible to tunnel SCTP over UDP,[2] as well as mapping TCP API calls to SCTP ones.

    Sly Technologies Inc.

      • source

        @Field(format="%d",
       offset=0,
       length=16)
public int source()
        This is the SCTP sender's port number. It can be used by the receiver in combination with the source IP address, the SCTP destination port, and possibly the destination IP address to identify the association to which this packet belongs. The port number 0 MUST NOT be used.
        ����:
        source port number
        �������:
        RFC4960

      • destination

        @Field(format="%d",
       offset=16,
       length=16)
public int destination()
        This is the SCTP port number to which this packet is destined. The receiving host will use this port number to de-multiplex the SCTP packet to the correct receiving endpoint/application. The port number 0 MUST NOT be used.
        ����:
        destination port number
        �������:
        RFC4960

      • destination

        public void destination(int port)
        This is the SCTP port number to which this packet is destined. The receiving host will use this port number to de-multiplex the SCTP packet to the correct receiving endpoint/application. The port number 0 MUST NOT be used.
        ����:
        port - destination port number
        �������:

      • tag

        @Field(format="%x",
       offset=32,
       length=32)
public long tag()
        The receiver of this packet uses the Verification Tag to validate the sender of this SCTP packet. On transmit, the value of this Verification Tag MUST be set to the value of the Initiate Tag received from the peer endpoint during the association initialization, with the following exceptions:
        • A packet containing an INIT chunk MUST have a zero Verification Tag.
        • A packet containing a SHUTDOWN COMPLETE chunk with the T bit set MUST have the Verification Tag copied from the packet with the SHUTDOWN ACK chunk.
        • A packet containing an ABORT chunk may have the verification tag copied from the packet that caused the ABORT to be sent. For details see RFC 4960 Section 8.4 and Section 8.5.
        ����:
        verification tag
        �������:
        RFC4960

      • tag

        public void tag(long tag)
        The receiver of this packet uses the Verification Tag to validate the sender of this SCTP packet. On transmit, the value of this Verification Tag MUST be set to the value of the Initiate Tag received from the peer endpoint during the association initialization, with the following exceptions:
        • A packet containing an INIT chunk MUST have a zero Verification Tag.
        • A packet containing a SHUTDOWN COMPLETE chunk with the T bit set MUST have the Verification Tag copied from the packet with the SHUTDOWN ACK chunk.
        • A packet containing an ABORT chunk may have the verification tag copied from the packet that caused the ABORT to be sent. For details see RFC 4960 Section 8.4 and Section 8.5.
        ����:
        tag - verification tag

      • checksum

        @Field(offset=64,
       length=32,
       format="%x",
       name="checksum")
public int checksum()
        This field contains the checksum of this SCTP packet. Its calculation is discussed in RFC 4960 Section 6.8. SCTP uses the CRC32c algorithm as described in RFC 4960 Appendix B for calculating the checksum.
        ָ����:

      • checksum

        public boolean checksum(int crc)
        This field contains the checksum of this SCTP packet. Its calculation is discussed in RFC 4960 Section 6.8. SCTP uses the CRC32c algorithm as described in Appendix B for calculating the checksum.
        ָ����:
        checksum �ڽӿ��� JHeaderChecksum
        ����:
        crc - value of the checksum field
        ����:
        true if setter succeeded, or false if unable to set the checksum such as when its the case when header is truncated or not complete
        �������:
        RFC4960

      • isChecksumValid

        public boolean isChecksumValid()
        �ӽӿڸ��Ƶ�˵��: JHeaderChecksum
        Validates the header's data against the stored checksum. Checksums for partial headers or fragmented packets (unless the protocol allows it) are not validated and true is always returned.
        ָ����:
        isChecksumValid �ڽӿ��� JHeaderChecksum
        ����:
        Calculates a checksum and validates it against the store checksum in the header. If checksums match or header is a fragment true is returned, otherwise if the checksums don't match false is returned.
